div1.p: Hench gives suggestions of publishers for Reed's manuscript. He also lists errors in her manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed, June 18, 1941
div1.opener:
To Mrs. Blossom Reed
June 18, 1941
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Since I was unable to spend as much time on your father's letters as
I had hoped, I had my secretary copy a number of the letters in full, but I can
assure you I will not use these letters, except to give your background notes,
without your special permission. Since returning, I read them over again and I
agree with you that they are certainly most interesting and should by all means
be published somewhere if possible. I imagine that some editors to whom you
might send them might think much of the data was too personal, but it does certainly
show his wonderful character. As I see it, the present day editor of magazines
for laymen wants to jazz up most articles. You may have read the story of Moran
published in the Saturday Evening Post two or three years ago. Someone interviewed
Moran, took the main parts of his story and then jazzed it up considerably.

Andrus, one of the volunteers (as a matter of fact, the one who presumably
volunteered to take the place of your father when he insisted on submitting to the
mosquito bites) has written his story up briefly and has sent it to one or two
magazines for publication but it was sent back with the usual regrets. I think
there is probably no question that the letters would be published in some medical
or some medical historical journal but these journals do not pay for manuscripts
and your only reward would be the satisfaction of having your father's character
adequately portrayed. Had you thought of enlisting the interest of the University
of Virginia? Most large universities have a university press and of all institutions,
the University of Virginia would be most interested. The librarian there, Mr. Harry
Clemons, is most interested in the yellow fever story. They have a small Walter
Reed collection of data already. Incidentally, my brother, Dr. A. L. Hench, is
Professor of English Literature there and I would be very glad, should you wish me
to do so, to send him your manuscript and have him discuss it with Mr. Clemons.
Perhaps you would prefer to write Mr. Clemons directly. I understand from our
editorial department that Little Brown of Boston, lay publishers, are interested
in stories with a medical angle. I do not know anyone there but perhaps they would
be interested in your manuscript. I am returning it to you today by insured express.
May I ask you a few questions regarding your manuscript?

1. In reading them, it seemed to me that the letters of March 6, 1876
(your page 36) and that of April 3, 1876 (your page 39) were written in the opposite
sequence. The one now marked April 3 was apparently written before the one marked
March 6. I suspect that both of these letters were written either in April or in
March.
2. Do you have the date of the first letter on your page 71? my p 1

my p 1 3. In the letter on page 71, should it be Major Petterson, with two “t's”
or Peterson with one “t”?

Mrs. Blossom Reed
- 2 -
June 18, 1941

my p 2 4. Your page 72, letter of “Sunday, 1 P.M.” Your letter suggests that
your father's boat was running parallel to the shore at a distance of about two
hundred miles. He then mentions the sights on the beach. Surely this must be a
mistake. The boat must have been running parallel to the shore at two or at most
twenty miles, and not two hundred miles. Could you check this with the original
letter.

my p 7 5. Your page 78. The letter on this page mentions “The Evening Star”
paper. Does your mother recall what city and what the date of this paper was?
I suspect it may have been a Washington paper. I should very much like to trace
this article.

my p 9 6. Your page 80. In the letter of July 19, a Dr. Durleam is mentioned.
I am sure that this is Dr. Durham.

my p 10 7. Your page 81. You have the “Transport Rawlines”. I am sure it was
the “Rawlins.”

my p 10 8. Your page 82. Do you have any idea of the date of the letter dated
“Monday afternoon, 5 P.M.”? The mailing date might be on the envelope.

my p 11 9. Your page 84. The sentence given in your manuscript, “His name will
live in history of those who have benefited humanity.” I wonder if this sentence
is correctly quoted?

p 13-14 10. Page 86. For my own personal information I would appreciate greatly
knowing who are the three “Doctors__________”. In the letter of December 11,
pages 86 and 87. I will keep this in confidence but would very much like to know.

my p 18 11. Page 93. In the letter of December 23, your father mentions an
article in the Washington Post. I assume this was sometime during the month of
December. Do you or your mother happen to have this clipping or the date of this
article?

my p 19 12. Page 94. Are you sure your father's letter was dated December 26 or
should this have been on the 25th, Christmas Day? On the bottom of page 95, your
father speaks of the young fellow “who went in on the twenty-first and was suddenly
stricken today at noon.” This must refer to Moran and the official record shows that
he became sick on Christmas afternoon.

my p 23 13. Your page 98. You quote “and I must check for a while this letter.”
Is that an accurate quotation from the original letter?

my p 23 14. Page 99. You mention the number of letters which have been given away.
Again I would be so happy to help to try to collect copies of these letters if your
mother could give me some idea of those to whom these letters were sent. I should
be glad to write around and collect for you and myself copies of these letters.
This also applies to the distressing absence of letters between October 6 and December
9, in addition to those missing letters of February, 1901.

Let me say again what a privilege it has been for me to read these letters
and if I can help in any way further, I should be glad to do so. Should you finally
decide that the only thing to do is to have them published without financial return
to you, I will be glad to give you the names of three or four medical historical
journals but I still believe that the University of Virginia might be the best bet.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh: ds
